Invitation to the Capital-as-a-Service Beta!

Pitch Us Today!


** Your chance to apply for funding right now
------------------------------------------------------------

Thank you for signing up to receive updates about Capital-as-a-Service from Social Capital (original post (http://www.socialcapital.com/caas/) ). We're slowly opening up our beta to new people, and have selected you in our latest batch of invitees!
Get Funded Here! (https://caas.socialcapital.com)
Wondering whether your company is a good fit for CaaS? We‚Äôve put together some FAQs below with information about how the process works (with a bit more detail than on our site).

Thanks again for your interest. Please don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out with any comments, questions or feedback on the experience.

Sincerely,
Will and the Capital-as-a-Service team

~FAQS~

Is my company currently a good fit for CaaS?

Right now, Capital-as-a-Service requires companies with at least 3 months of traction data (post launch), and primarily makes co-investments. This means we can only fund companies who have other backers joining in the round, and cannot fully commit until terms have been set.

If you're currently pre-product, or newly launched, we'd encourage you to apply when you‚Äôre further along.

How much money is CaaS investing at this time?

At this time, CaaS writes checks between $50K to 250K USD, depending on a variety of factors. It is for this reason that we do not lead rounds, and prefer to act as co-investors. As the program develops, these guidelines may change.

Are there any categories Capital-as-a-Service will not fund?
Unfortunately, at this time, we do not make investments into Alcohol, Gambling, and other 'vice' related industries.

How long does the process take?

The process of receiving capital from Social Capital via CaaS (if we decide to invest) can be divided into 2 parts: the diligence process, and the closing process. As we scale and adjust our processes to handle a greater number of companies, the decision process itself, currently takes 7-10 business days (including a bit of buffer), and works as follows:

1. Application (<1 day): You complete the application, including uploading the requested data.

3. Conversation about Analysis (3-6 days): We'll follow up over email if we have any questions resulting from our quant analysis, and give you and your team the opportunity to provide notes and thoughts on our insights.

4. Internal Review & Decision (1-2 days): Once we‚Äôre satisfied with the combination of our quantitative analysis and have clarified any misinterpretations of data, we‚Äôll get back to you with a final decision (pending the terms of the round, as set by the lead investor).

The closing process is a bit less rigid and depends on a variety of factors, most notably, where you are in the fundraising round (we cannot start the closing process until your terms are set and the round is agreed upon), and your country of incorporation. Once we have all the proper documentation, we are usually able to close within 10 business days.

News: Greater transparency of Council legislative process, fundamental for representative democracy, says European Ombudsman

Madrid, 13 February 2018 - Access Info today welcomed the European
Ombudsman recommendation that the Council of the European Union increase
transparency of its legislative process in...

 Greater transparency of Council legislative process, fundamental for
representative democracy, says European Ombudsman
 Madrid, 13 February 2018

 Click here <https://www.access-info.org/article/30314>
to read this article online.

 Access Info Europe <https://www.access-info.org>
today welcomed the European Ombudsman recommendation that the Council of
the European Union increase transparency of its legislative process in
order to guarantee citizens' right to hold their elected representatives to
account and to participate in the democratic life of the EU.

 Two main findings of the Ombudsman's inquiry into transparency of the
Council, to which Access Info submitted a series of proposals
<https://www.access-info.org/article/30167>
in December 2017, are that the Council's systematic failure to record the
names of Member States along with their positions on legislative matters
constitutes maladministration, and that there is over-classification of
documents as ‚ÄúLIMITE‚Äù, which restricts their circulation.

 The Ombudsman recommends that the Council systematically record the
identity of Member States, including at preparatory stages of legislative
procedures.

 This recommendation is in line with the case of Council v. Access Info
Europe, won by Access Info <https://www.access-info.org/eut/12303>
on 17 October 2013, in which the Court of Justice of the EU established the
right of the public to access documents containing the names of Member
States putting forward legislative proposals, even at early stages of
debate.

 ‚ÄúIt is positive that, following the landmark 2013 Court ruling, the
Council now releases documents containing Member State names upon request,
but poor record keeping often makes this meaningless and undermines
accountability of EU institutions and EU Member states,‚Äù stated Helen
Darbishire, Executive Director of Access Info Europe.

 The Ombudsman also called for the development by the Council of clear
criteria for using the ‚ÄòLIMITE' status. The current absence of such
guidelines is something that had been highlighted by Access Info in its
submission as problematic, often resulting in an over-broad classification
on documents as LIMITE which severely limits public scrutiny.

 Access Info notes that the Council has recently shown itself ready to
improve transparency with changes to its website ongoing. On 16 January
2017, Access Info's Helen Darbishire was invited to give a talk to Council
representatives, which was followed by a discussion on solutions to opening
up the legislative process.

 ‚ÄúIt is imperative that the Council take the Ombudsman's recommendations
seriously and act to address deficiencies in transparency, because the
secrecy surrounding Council decision making is contributing to a lack of
public trust in European Union institutions,‚Äù added Darbishire.

 The European Ombudsman's recommendations to the Council on the
transparency of its legislative process can be found here
<https://www.ombudsman.europa.eu/en/cases/recommendation.faces/en/89518/html.bookmark>

 For more information, please contact:

 Luisa Izuzquiza, Communications Officer | Access Info Europe

 Helen Darbishire, Executive Director | Access Info Europe

 Send an e-mail <http://www.access-info.org/about-us>
or call +34 913 656 558
